Unfortunate? This is the standard situation in most processes: Test are
written after development or in parallel to it. What's so unfortunate about
writing tests?

I would recommend that you read Boris Beizer's "Black Box Testing" -
although I'm still struggling how to integrate its wisdom with modern
tooling, it is definitely worth to get a grip on "pure testing" (the
"tester's job").

Technically, I do not see why you shouldn't be able to write unit tests for
selected classes with JUnit - if the design is suitable.

But of course there are many more ways to skin a cat - various xUnit tools;
but also GUI testing tools [not for you], load testing tools (very
expensive!), and many more.

So you should first have an concept of 

* what you want to test: Functional correctness; but maybe also performance;
usability; reliability; ...

* to which level of granularity, e.g.
  - methods of single classes; or of facade classes hiding a complete
"system";
  - single web page clicks, or whole work-flows;

* to which level of quality, e.g.
  - only critical functions (e.g. defined by "draw most bug reports in the
last 3 monts");
  - everything to some coverage level; then you need to decide on 
  -- the coverage level ("80%" is in "industry standard"; "100% feasible
coverage" is the only sensible standard)
  -- the type of coverage (code coverage; or some "feature coverage" - all
the features down written in some specification or documentation)

... I hope this wasn't too general ...
